title: Are invading and counterjungling fun?
body:
One of the new preseason changes is to add items to allow for stronger invading and counter-jungling.

Riot say that this will encourage junglers into player-vs-player activities, but I have to ask: are these activities actually fun?

Right now, junglers are very... unbalanced.  You mostly see invades happening by the likes of Lee Sin, who is guaranteed to win any early-game 1v1 against all but a very small number of junglers, so instead of "an interesting 1v1 fight in the jungle", being invaded by him tends to be more "I got invaded at level 2 by Lee Sin, since he's an unbeatable duellist, I'm either dead, or blew my flash and lost my buffs."

Counterjungling is similar; you get someone like Udyr, who is almost impossible to catch, running into the jungle, taking buffs, and then running away.  He's less like to murder you, but his combination of tankiness and damage means that most junglers can't punish him for invading since he will also win a 1v1, and if the laners try to collapse on him, he can usually just outrun anyone and get away.

What this tends to mean is that, instead of an interesting 1v1 interaction, you get one player (the one with the strong duellist jungler) making life a complete pain for another (the one with the weaker duellist jungler), and often effectively removing that player's presence from the game.

Maybe it's just me, because I tend to play junglers who are not the handful of top-tier duellists, but I don't find this particularly fun.

Are there plans to add something else to help support the junglers being invaded, so they have a chance against these strong duellist champions?

Let me turn the question around: What exactly is an example of fun? Do you find aiming a skillshot at an enemy champion fun? I feel that most things that are 'fun' don't seem fun anymore when viewed objectively.

Even if counterjungling/invading isn't 'fun', there are still reasons it should exist. For the same reasons that getting killed is unfun yet is still a necessary feature of the game, jungler-jungler interaction should also exist; invade and counterjungle are two examples.

If someone is naturally a better duelist than you, then why shouldn't they be able to leverage their advantage? If Syndra can abuse Fizz in midlane, why shouldn't Lee be able to abuse Sejuani in the jungle? If it's because Lee is able to do everything Sejuani can but better, then that's because Lee is broken - not because counterjungling is broken.

The vision counterplay to invades is also now more robust. First of all, Crab and Wolf grant areas of vision control: Crab controls a river chokepoint, and Wolf is capable of scouting an entire quadrant of the jungle. This means that, if you're afraid of the enemy jungler, you have the power to pick the proper jungle rewards to stop them. You can also use green trinket defensively for where the Crab and Wolf don't cover. If anything, you have more options than before against invades.

I'm going to qualify this a little bit.

I think that the problems that I pointed out with invading and counterjungling are primary caused by certain jungler champions.

I think that counterjungling is fun when the enemy jungler doing it takes risks to do it.  Sneaking into the jungle and stealing a blue buff when you see the enemy jungler in another lane is interesting, with risks and benefits.

The problem I have with counterjungling is when it's done by champions who don't care.  Champions who can come in and take a buff, and don't care if the enemy jungler finds them there because they have no fear of dying to the enemy jungler.  Udyr is the most obvious example of this (even if you catch him at your buff, he can usually tank you, and often even another laner, for long enough to get away.)
Hecarim and Shyvana used to be other examples of this (though I don't see those jungling lately.)

I think that the important thing here is *risk*.
If the enemy jungler is taking a risk, where if they don't do the invade/counterjungling properly, they can lose, then it's interesting.
But when you have one-sided situations where the invader is almost guaranteed to get a kill (or a Flash), or the invader has no real fear of being caught for their counterjungling, then it's not fun.  It feels like you've lost because of champion choices rather than because of skill, which never feels like fun.

On the side of invading, if the invade will only succeed if you get the drop on the enemy jungler, but if they have warded and seen you coming, they can turn around and surprise you and kill you instead, then it's interesting.  If your champion is guaranteed to win the fight even if they surprise you, then it's not.  It's losing based on champion picks.

How exactly do you stop it though? Udyr and Lee Sin are meant to be duelists, so they should be able to duel. In the early levels one dueling champion is going to outduel one tanky champion. Unless you make every single jungler a dueling or tanking champion.

Counter jungling is one of those things that needs to exist because there needs to be a way to punish passive junglers and to make the ganking ones have to weigh the options of going in lane vs making sure their jungle buffs are secure.
I think the bigger problem is all the passive jungler suck right now, except mumu. That ult plus % dmg, never fair.

As a jungle main I like counter jungling. It's a mini game in of itself and always changing. However, when I get counter jungled it can be very annoying but at the same time it's just part of the game. If you jungle long enough you can find ways around counter jungling. For those that don't jungle then yea, it'll probably be harder and less forgiving but it'll emphasize the difference between a good jungler and an ordinary jungler just like how lanes are played. I've played many matches where I have gotten ahead of the enemy jungler but because of team fights the difference has turned out negligible. I really like that Riot is giving the jungle some love: treating it like a solo lane. It will leave a lot of room for outplay potential and more team coordination. 

Please keep in mind that all these changes have yet to be finalized. There isn't much point in getting worked up about it until release.

I find being killed to be highly unfun. Late game, being killed can cause you to be out of control of your champion for upwards of FORTY SECONDS-Riot nerfed 3 second hard ccs for exactly this reason. Why not remove dying entirely, resulting in 100% player agency in order to win games? 

On a more serious note, I feel like you're missing counterplay that you actually do have. Even currently, let's say i'm laning as a tank, vs a Lee Sin. What I'm going to do is start with my warding trinket, and start at the opposite buff from the traditional configuration (for instance, start red as Amumu). Then, after I finish my leashed buff, I place my trinket in the bush on the far side of the camp, and I head up towards my blue buff. If by some chance the enemy team invaded me, or Lee Sin is psychic, I have red buff and I go and make an unexpected level 2 gank on an enemy to burn a flash/get a kill and snowball my friendly lane. If not, I will spot Lee Sin heading to my (gone) red buff, claim my doubles before he has a chance to, AND I have the knowledge that he is on the opposite side of the map so I can enter a lane and be super aggressive in order to get a nasty gank off. Lee Sin loses a huge chunk of his early game threat, I'm safe and secure in the knowledge that I scale infinitely better than him, I got off a really solid gank and my team knows exactly where he is, and it was almost zero risk to me. 

and, to add on to that, I think you're forgetting the counterplay they're adding in to the new strategies they're creating. That wolf smite bonus is going to be quite powerful when combined to the already available counterplay you can get through warding and communication. If an enemy enters your jungle to counter, and you spot them with a ward, advantage goes to you 100%-you know where they are, and you have the choice of either popping into their jungle then ganking from a really unexpected angle, or just going and hammering one of the enemy lanes.

I get it. People don't like their routines screwed with when jungling, and it stinks when someone kills you in the jungle. But the key here is that you had options to deal with that and you didn't-that's on you, not them.

This kind of invade I'm all for because it's easily counterable by a well placed ward, and it doesn't hinder jungler options.

The type of invades I'm NOT ok with are the ones that Shaco and Lee Sin are (in)famous for:  sitting in your red bush and either fearing you with a jack-in-the-box, and proceeding to backstab you to death, or smacking you with a tempest/sonic wave resonating strike combo, and literally kicking the shit out of you.  This leads to you getting super behind, and stifles the champion pool to amounts that would make Occam's Razor cut itself for the idea.  And lo and behold, what champions are taking the piss out of jungle right now?  {{champion:64}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:28}}.  If Shaco didnt' have that ridiculous buff identifier on his clones, he'd probably be up there too.  Of course Lee Sin is the brown top hat of the shit show that is jungler diversity because he fosters an unhealthy fanbase of rabid freelo whiners that derailed his rework that would have arguably balanced the champion.

Invading and counter-jungling have been pretty much worthless this season with the jungle changes to make catching up easier (camps give more xp if you're under leveled and there are more camps than there were in S3). It's a better allocation of time to simply farm and gank, but trying to stalk the enemy jungler to keep him behind is pretty much a trivial pursuit. If you can take a first buff or get first blood by invading, that's good, but other than that counterjungling is pretty pointless for putting someone behind.

It doesn't feel fun to be on the receiving end of counterjungling and invading if you don't know what to do, but I think it added another layer of complexity to jungling. In S3 when it was prominent, I played both very strong early game junglers capable of counter jungling, and very weak early game junglers who were very likely to be counterjungled. This interraction between junglers made the matchup most of the time, and my knowledge of how to properly counterjungle and avoid being counterjungled made jungling more dynamic. At this time, junglers for the most part only interact in a counterganking scenario.
